meta.title: Build Your Child's Bedtime Routine
meta.description: A research-backed assessment to evaluate your current bedtime routine and get personalized recommendations. Based on sleep research from the Sleep Foundation and AAP guidelines.
meta.intro:
A solid bedtime routine isn't about perfection — it's about consistency, calm, and setting your child up for the sleep their body needs. This quiz helps you see where your routine is already strong and where small tweaks could make a big difference.

Answer based on what typically happens, not your best night or worst night.

sources.name: American Academy of Pediatrics — Sleep Guidelines

questions.text: How consistent is your child's bedtime throughout the week?
questions.subtext: Think about weeknights and weekends combined.
questions.source: AAP — consistent sleep schedules reduce sleep resistance

options.text: Within 15-30 minutes every night, including weekends
Consistent on weeknights, but shifts by 1-2 hours on weekends
Varies widely depending on the day

questions.text: What time does your child typically fall asleep on weeknights?
questions.source: Sleep Foundation — age-appropriate bedtimes support sleep needs

options.text: Before 8:30pm (ages 1-5) or before 9:00pm (ages 6-8)
Between 8:30-9:30pm (ages 1-5) or 9:00-10:00pm (ages 6-8)
After 9:30pm (ages 1-5) or after 10:00pm (ages 6-8)

questions.text: How long does it typically take your child to fall asleep after lights-out?
questions.subtext: Once they're in bed, how long until they're actually asleep?
questions.source: Sleep Foundation — sleep onset latency as routine effectiveness indicator

options.text: Usually within 15-20 minutes
20-45 minutes of settling, singing, talking
Over an hour, or requires a parent to stay until asleep

questions.text: What does the hour before bed typically look like?
questions.subtext: Think about the energy level and activities.
questions.source: AAP — wind-down routines signal the body to prepare for sleep

options.text: Calm and predictable — same sequence most nights (bath, books, songs)
Varies, but we aim for calm activities
Often hectic — late dinners, active play, or screen time right up to bed

questions.text: When does screen time (TV, tablet, phone) end before bed?
questions.subtext: Including your own phone while reading bedtime stories.
questions.source: Sleep Foundation — blue light suppresses melatonin production

options.text: At least 60 minutes before bedtime, or no screens in the evening
About 30 minutes before bed
Right up until bedtime, or screens in the bedroom

questions.text: Does your child have a predictable bedtime routine?
questions.subtext: A sequence of 3-5 steps that happens in the same order most nights.
questions.source: AAP — predictable routines reduce bedtime resistance and anxiety

options.text: Yes, same steps in the same order every night
We do similar things but the order varies
No consistent routine — bedtime just kind of happens

questions.text: What is the lighting situation in your child's bedroom at sleep time?
questions.subtext: Including nightlights, hall lights, or streetlights coming through windows.
questions.source: Sleep Foundation — darkness supports melatonin production

options.text: Very dark — blackout curtains or minimal light
Dim nightlight or some ambient light from hallway
Bright nightlight, overhead light, or significant light from windows/hallway

questions.text: How would you describe your child's bedroom temperature at night?
questions.subtext: Think about whether they wake up sweaty or cold.
questions.source: Sleep Foundation — cooler rooms (60-67°F) optimize sleep quality

options.text: Cool and comfortable — around 65-68°F
A bit warm or a bit cold, but not uncomfortable
Too warm or too cold — they wake up sweaty or need extra blankets

questions.text: Is your child's bedroom used only for sleep, or for other activities too?
questions.subtext: Play, homework, TV — or just a sleep space?
questions.source: Sleep Foundation — bedroom as sleep-only space strengthens sleep associations

options.text: Mostly just for sleep — toys and play happen elsewhere
Some play happens there, but we transition to 'bedroom = sleep' mode at night
The bedroom is where they play, watch TV, and sleep

high.headline: Strong sleep hygiene practices
high.detail: You've built a predictable, calming pre-sleep routine that signals your child's body it's time to wind down. This consistency — same steps, same order, no screens — is the foundation of good sleep. The routine doesn't have to be fancy, just reliable.
high.strength: Excellent pre-sleep routine — your child's body knows what to expect and when

medium.headline: Good foundations, room for refinement
medium.detail: You're doing some things right — calming activities, mostly consistent — but there are a few gaps that could be smoothed out. Small tweaks to screen time cutoffs or routine predictability can have outsized effects on sleep onset.
medium.concern: Sleep hygiene has some inconsistencies — tightening up screen time and routine order will help your child settle faster

low.headline: Routine needs more structure
low.detail: Your pre-sleep period is unpredictable or stimulating, which makes it hard for your child's body to know when sleep is coming. Building a short, repeatable sequence — even just 3 steps in the same order every night — dramatically improves sleep onset within a week or two.
low.concern: Sleep hygiene is inconsistent or stimulating. A predictable 3-5 step routine (bath, brush teeth, books, songs, lights out) signals the body to prepare for sleep.

high.headline: Rock-solid schedule consistency
high.detail: Your child goes to bed and falls asleep around the same time every night, which keeps their internal clock aligned. This predictability reduces bedtime resistance and makes mornings easier too. Weekend consistency is the hardest part, and you're nailing it.
high.strength: Highly consistent sleep schedule — your child's internal clock is well-regulated

medium.headline: Mostly consistent with some drift
medium.detail: Weeknights are solid, but weekends throw things off — or bedtime is consistent but it takes a long time to actually fall asleep. Tightening up weekend timing by even 30 minutes can reduce Monday-morning grumpiness and improve sleep quality across the week.
medium.concern: Schedule consistency drifts on weekends or sleep onset takes too long — tightening bedtime windows will strengthen your child's internal rhythm

low.headline: Schedule needs more consistency
low.detail: Bedtime shifts significantly night to night, or your child is going to sleep later than their body needs. This variability confuses the internal clock, making it harder to fall asleep and wake up. Picking a target bedtime and sticking to it within 30 minutes — even on weekends — resets the system surprisingly fast.
low.concern: Irregular bedtime or late sleep onset disrupts circadian rhythm. Aim for the same bedtime (±30 min) every night, including weekends, for 2 weeks and watch resistance decrease.

high.headline: Optimized sleep environment
high.detail: Your child's bedroom is cool, dark, and associated primarily with sleep. These environmental cues — especially darkness and temperature — work with their biology to support deep, restorative sleep. You've set up the conditions for success.
high.strength: Sleep-friendly environment — cool, dark, and dedicated to rest

medium.headline: Good environment with minor distractions
medium.detail: The bedroom is mostly sleep-friendly but has a few factors working against you — too much light, too warm, or used for play during the day. Small fixes (blackout curtains, lowering the thermostat 2 degrees, moving toys to another space) often yield immediate improvements.
medium.concern: Sleep environment has some disruptors — adjusting light, temperature, or bedroom activities can improve sleep quality

low.headline: Environment needs sleep optimization
low.detail: The bedroom is too bright, too warm, or too stimulating. These factors make it physiologically harder for your child to fall asleep and stay asleep. The good news: environmental fixes are often the easiest and fastest wins. Blackout shades and a cooler room can change everything.
low.concern: Sleep environment works against your routine. Prioritize darkness (blackout curtains), cooler temps (65-68°F), and minimizing non-sleep activities in the bedroom.

ready.headline: Rock-Solid Routine
ready.subheadline: You've built a strong, consistent bedtime routine that supports your child's sleep needs.
ready.explanation: Your routine is consistent, calming, and aligned with what sleep research tells us works. Your child's environment is optimized, their schedule is predictable, and their pre-sleep routine signals their body it's time to rest. Keep doing what you're doing.
nextSteps: Protect the routine during travel or disruptions — even a shortened version maintains the pattern
If sleep issues arise, revisit the domains below to troubleshoot — small drifts in consistency can have big effects
As your child grows, expect the routine to evolve (less singing, more independent reading) but keep the core structure
Share your routine sequence with caregivers and grandparents so your child gets the same cues wherever they sleep
ready.watchOutFor: Even with a great routine, sleep needs change. If your child starts resisting bedtime or waking frequently, check whether their sleep needs have shifted — a 5-year-old sleeping 12 hours might need a slightly later bedtime as they approach 6.
ready.encouragement: You've built something rare: a bedtime routine that actually works. That didn't happen by accident — it happened because you prioritized consistency even when it was inconvenient. That discipline pays off in better sleep for everyone.
ready.comparativeContext: Families with routines this strong typically report fewer bedtime battles and better sleep quality across the week.
ready.retakeAdvice: No need to retake unless something changes in your routine or sleep environment

almost.headline: Almost There
almost.subheadline: You have good sleep foundations — tightening up a few areas will make bedtime easier.
almost.explanation: You're doing many things right, but there are gaps — inconsistent timing, lingering screens, a too-bright bedroom, or a routine that varies night to night. The domains below show you where to focus. Small, specific changes often have immediate effects.
nextSteps: Pick ONE domain below to improve first — don't overhaul everything at once
If schedule consistency is low: commit to the same bedtime (±15 minutes) for 2 weeks, even on weekends
If sleep hygiene is low: build a simple 3-step routine (bath, books, bed) and repeat it in the same order every night
If sleep environment is low: start with darkness (blackout curtains or shades) and temperature (aim for 65-68°F)
Track changes for a week — bedtime struggles often improve within 3-5 nights of consistent routines
almost.watchOutFor: The hardest part of routine-building is the first week. Your child will resist changes to familiar patterns — later bedtimes feel like freedom, even if they're causing problems. Expect pushback. Stick with it. Sleep pressure builds, and within days the new routine starts to feel normal.
almost.encouragement: You're closer than you think. The difference between 'almost there' and 'rock solid' is usually just 2-3 specific fixes repeated consistently. You don't need to be perfect — you just need to be predictable.
almost.comparativeContext: Most families who tighten up one domain see noticeable improvements in sleep onset and bedtime cooperation within 1-2 weeks.
almost.retakeAdvice: Retake this quiz in 2-3 weeks after implementing changes to track progress

not-yet.headline: Fresh Start
not-yet.subheadline: Your routine needs more structure — but this is fixable, and the changes pay off fast.
not-yet.explanation: Right now, bedtime is unpredictable, inconsistent, or working against your child's biology. This isn't a judgment — it's information. Building a routine from scratch feels overwhelming, but you don't need to change everything at once. Start small, stay consistent, and sleep improves within days.
nextSteps: Start with one anchor: pick a bedtime and stick to it every night for 2 weeks (±15 min), even if it feels early
Build the simplest possible routine: 3 steps, same order, every night (example: bath → brush teeth → 2 books → lights out)
Cut screens 60 minutes before bed — this one change often has the biggest immediate effect on sleep onset
Make the bedroom darker and cooler — blackout curtains and a fan are cheap fixes with outsized results
Expect resistance for 3-5 nights as your child's body adjusts to the new rhythm, then expect cooperation to improve
not-yet.watchOutFor: If bedtime has been chaotic, your child may push back hard when you introduce structure. They're not being difficult — they're used to the old pattern, even if it didn't work. Consistency breaks through resistance faster than negotiation. Hold the boundary kindly but firmly.
not-yet.encouragement: You're starting from scratch, and that's actually an advantage — you're not trying to tweak a broken system, you're building a new one. Sleep routines respond to consistency faster than almost any other parenting challenge. Two weeks of boring repetition creates a bedtime that works.
not-yet.comparativeContext: Families who commit to 2 weeks of strict routine-building typically see dramatic reductions in bedtime resistance and sleep onset time.
not-yet.retakeAdvice: Retake this quiz in 3-4 weeks after establishing a consistent routine
